STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 16, 2022
Alison Morrison
Shiawassee County DHHS
1720 E Main St
Owosso, MI 48867
RE: License #: CP780201406
Shiawassee County DHHS
1720 E Main St
Owosso, MI 48867
Dear Ms. Morrison:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
9/15/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statues and rules.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts
Page 19
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face
contacts listed below in the electronic case management
record within five business days of the contact. This
includes attempted and missed face-to-face contacts.
Three of six foster care files held case contacts that were not entered timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
10/15/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 10/28/2021
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
Page 2
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents if the child is a temporary court
ward. Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
One of six foster care files did not have quarterly updated Medical Passports as
required.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Page 10
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the
electronic case record within 30 days of the report date.
One of six foster care files held treatment plans that were not signed within 30 days
of the report date.
FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting
Page 6
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
4

One of six foster care files had a Family Team Meeting on file, without a completed
1105 document.
FOM 722-08E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
Page 3
Three days prior to a planned placement change, or within
three business days of an emergency placement change,
the caseworker must document…
One of six foster care files did not have DHHS-69’s completed timely for two
replacements.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
10/15/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 10/28/2021
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 CPR/First Aid documentation- documentation of updated training should be
obtained at the time of completion and placed in the file.
 Emergency Procedures- Foster parents are required to practice and
document emergency procedures once every four months, regardless of
whether there are foster children placed in the home.
 Borrowed Beds- All requirements from the borrowed bed rule must be
followed and a file created, even if the foster home is borrowed from
Shiawassee’s dual county (Gratiot) with whom a licensing supervisor is
shared.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following area:
 Special Evaluations- consultation was provided to the licensing supervisor
and worker regarding an open special evaluation (SE). The SE remains open
after several months due to the involvement of law enforcement (LE). The
agency has completed the required extensions for completion of the SE. The
agency was advised to keep the SE open until they receive findings from LE,
as it could make a significant impact on licensing findings.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
A CAP, approved 10/28/2021, was developed after the 10/15/2021 interim review.
The CAP addressed violations about providing the Independent Living (IL) program
statement and policy/procedures to youth, supervision of IL youth, timeliness of
action summaries, and timely entry of case contacts. During the current review
period, two repeat violations were established. Both repeat violations were contract
5

items, with a minimal number of occurrences. The agency demonstrated successful
implementation of the CAP regarding IL policy/rules.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator assessment was reviewed and discussed on-site. The Chief
Administrator (CA) reported there was staff changes during this review period,
including two supervisors. The agency reported having an otherwise stable team,
with few vacancies. The CA further reported they continue to struggle with locating
placements at times, due to the state-wide placement crisis. Many youth are in need
of residential treatment, but options are limited. Regarding the CAP from the 2021
review, the CA reported successful implementation and improvement regarding IL
files. Implementation occurred through case reviews, focus on placement change
documents, peer reviews, mini-audits, and engagement of all staff in CAP
compliance. The agency continues these practices and will roll in any actions steps
from the CAP developed after this review.
Interviews
Interviews were completed on-site with two staff: one foster care and one licensing.
Both staff reported feeling supported by the agency. Both staff indicated they have
helpful, organized, and knowledgeable supervisors, and manageable caseloads.
Staff reported difficulty with finding placements at times. However, that is a known,
state-wide issue. Otherwise, neither staff had any concerns or ideas for
improvement.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued
a renewal of their regular license.
_ _____________September 16, 2022__________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 16, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
